segments.text: with Bob Mathis by Julie Hopson on 18 November 1988 at the custodial apartment in the physical plant at Texas A&M University concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oil History Collection and the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
That's fine with me.
Okay.
I need your date and place of birth.
November the 21st, 1941, Sport, Illinois.
Where did you go to school?
I went to school in several different places.
My father was in the military.
I graduated from high school in Inazuki, Japan.
Did you attend college?
I had two years of college in the University of Maryland.
What did you study?
Business.
Did you like it?
Well, I took it in sub-courses and everything when I was in the military in Germany.
University of Maryland goes all over Europe and they have classes at night.
Okay.
Why did you join the military?
Well, I wanted to be a soldier all my life.
My father was, uh, spent 28 years in the military and he was still on active duty when I graduated from high school.
My brother retired for 22 years as a First Sergeant in the Marine Corps.
And it's just something that my family's done all their lives.
I like the military.
How did you go about joining the military?
Well, I walked into the recruiting depot in Rapid City, South Dakota when I turned 18 years old and told them that I wanted to join.
And they told me that I had to have my parents' permission, so I went home and I got my mom and dad and we'd go back to
the recruiting depot, and they signed the papers, and I left the next day.
What year was this?
Is your brother older or younger than you?
Dick's older than I am.
What year did he join?
What branch did you join?
I joined the Army.
Why?
Well, at the time, I wanted to get married.
And I knew that to get rapid promotion, I had to get into a particular branch of service that had accelerated promotions.
I knew from being with my dad that the Air Force does not have accelerated promotions.
And I knew that the Marine Corps would keep you corporal for years.
So I was working for a guy named Casey Tips riding the fence line in South Dakota, and we had some Nike sites that was bordered our property.
And I talked to those guys, and they were all in the military, but they were in missiles.
And they said that the fastest thing was to join the armored cab units and be a recon specialist.
So that's what I did.
It took me 17 months to make sergeant.
When did you go to Vietnam?
The first time I went to Vietnam was in October of 1967.
What did you do in the Army between 1961 and 1967?
I was a recon specialist.
I worked for the armored cab units and guarding the Czech border and running border patrols and things like that in Germany.
Were you a German helicopter?
No.
I took my basic training at a place called Fort Ord, California.
I took my advanced training at Fort Knox, Kentucky.
And right after I got out of advanced training, I joined the 32nd Armored Battalion in Fort Stewart, Georgia.
And right after that, somebody in Berlin started building a brick wall.
And I gyroed to Europe with a 3rd Battalion, 32nd Armored, and I stayed there for three years.
I was a little upset about that because I had two days to go before I started my 30-day leave to get married.
And the 1st Sergeant tore up my leave papers, and we were all on alert.
I was going to strike one unit, and we all went to Germany on a boat.
Did you stay in Germany the whole time before you went to Vietnam?
No.
I stayed in Germany until 1964, and that was in southern Bavaria at a place called Augsburg.
which was about 60 miles north of Munich, a real nice place.
Cold a lot.
And then in 1964, I came back from Germany.
I went to a little summer spot called Fort Hood, Texas, which is really something else.
We'll talk about that when we're not on tape.
And then from Fort Hood, I stayed there nine months, and then I went to Fort Bliss.
I thought Hood was bad, but Bliss was worse.
This is when I heard about a little conflict called Vietnam, and I volunteered to go to Vietnam in 1965.
I got orders to go to Vietnam in 1966, and I was supposed to join the 11th Infantry Brigade in Hawaii, and we would go as a unit.
Well, I got to Hawaii in 1966.
I was set to go to Vietnam.
And there was myself and 11 other guys there.
And we were the nucleus of the 11th Infantry Brigade.
As a matter of record, there was a young captain there named Bill Carpenter, William Carpenter.
He's now a general officer.
All the guys in the military called him Maypom VI because he was put up for the Congressional Medal of Honor.
He was one of the first guys to call Maypom on his own position.
Somebody that's listened to this tape that knows anything about the military may recognize the name.
He was called the Lonesome Inn at West Point.
He played football.
But we got some of McNamara's 100,000.
Have you heard that term?
We got some of McNamara's 100,000 in Hawaii, and we trained them in the mountains in counterinsurgency operations, ambush techniques, and things like that for...

until October of 67 and then somebody thought that we needed to escalate the number of troops that were in South Vietnam so the 11th Infantry Brigade got three ships and it took us 33 days to get to South Vietnam.
Now we got there in 14 days but General Westmoreland did not know where he wanted to end service in the country so we sailed up and down the China Sea
for about 20 days until they figured that we needed to go into a little town called Duck Fo, which was just north of a place called Queen Yon, about 55 miles.
It was between Chew Line and Queen Yon.
Matter of fact, a little town called My Line is about 20 miles north of Duck Fo.
Why did it take two years almost from the time you
volunteers going to Vietnam for you to get there?
Well, I went to a unit.
I had a specific unit assignment.
And the 11th Infantry Brigade was a redesignated unit that they just brought back on paper.
It wasn't really a unit in itself because it didn't have all the people.
So they formed it on paper.
The 25th Infantry Division was out of Hawaii and already in Vietnam.
And
but they might not have been in Vietnam.
They were either in the Philippines or Thailand.
That's the Tropical Infantry Division, 25th Infantry Division.
And they were gone, so they needed a brigade in Hawaii.
And that's where we trained.
That was the best place we thought to train somebody for counterinsurgency because of the terrain and the rain and the mountains and the trails and stuff like that were
basically the same thing as South Vietnam.
So we got all these guys right out of basic training.
They didn't even go to their advanced training units.
They came straight out of basic training to us.
We gave them their advanced training, but it was all geared towards ambushes and counterinsurgency operations in South Vietnam.
What did y'all do when you got to Duckburg?
Well, the first thing we done was
set up a perimeter.
It was basically already there.
There was another unit there that had established the fire base.
There was a runway there and it was a brigade size fire base.
So when they gave us duck foe, they initially gave us an area of operations that required four battalions.
Now, we had left one battalion in Hawaii because it wasn't fully staffed yet, and they hadn't received all their training.
So until that battalion joined us in Hawaii, they made up a task force called Task Force Barker.
And what they did then is they pulled an empty company from each of the other three empty battalions, and they pulled a platoon from the recon troop that I was in.
Well, the platoon that I had went to Task Force Barker.
Now, this was...
Company C, which was Captain Medina's outfit that had Lieutenant Calley in it.
And then there was Captain Black.
I don't remember the other guy's name.
But Major Couch was the S3.
I don't remember the Sergeant Major's name.
And, of course, Colonel Barker was the task force commander.
And we assumed part of the area of operations, which was just north of Quang Nang.
Quang Nai was about 20 miles north of Duc Pho, and it was a major target for the Tet Offensive because it had a major airport.
And Quang Nai was about, I guess, 20 miles south of Chi Lai, which was the Americana Division.
When we first got there, we stayed as a separate brigade, separate infantry brigade.
And then, I guess, about right after Tet started,
They took the 193rd, the 198th, the 196th, the 11th Infantry Brigade, and another Infantry Brigade and put them all together and formed the Americal Division.
And the Americal Division headquarters was in July.
Did you see much action before that?
No, what they basically did at first is they sent us out with other units that were still in the area to learn
what the area looked like.
We basically fought, uh, BC, not too many NBAs.
Uh, and we just operated patrols, did some counterinsurgency operations, uh, and every time we'd get off the highway, we'd just start getting farther and farther back into the hills.
And we'd run over to the beach on the China Sea and we'd run up and down through, uh, my life in this one, through areas like that.
It was a real,

dominated area as far as the uh bc were concerned because they've been in there for years but it was basically uh i guess about the first four months we were there uh captain medina told me that he lost at least a third of his people to nothing but booby traps and uh he exhausted malaria and snipers so major contacts were not uh not really a
a problem with us.
It was the squad-sized ambushes and things like that.
The first year I was there, we didn't have any major battles.
Well, there was a couple.
They'd last a day or two, and we'd pull back, or they'd leave or hide or something.
Where were you when that occurred?
I was sitting on a bridge just north of Quang Mai.
that was supposed to be, it was right on Highway 1, and it was right outside of Arvin Fire Base.

And they were supposed to secure it, but it had been blown two or three times, and it was a Bailey Bridge put in by American engineers, so they put American troops on the bridges and pulled them back out of the field and just put them on these strong points so the VC wouldn't blow the bridges and cut our main supply routes.
And

We got a call from the task force commander, Colonel Barker, that morning that the Arvin advisors in Quang Nai would like an American force to come down and just ride around the city and show the South Vietnamese people that, hey, the Americans are here, their equipment's here, their men are here, and they're here to support us in this conflict against the North Vietnamese.
And we said, sure, we're not doing anything anyhow.
We went down to Quang Mai in 10 armored cab vehicles, and we were half-manded because we still had to maintain security for three bridges.
So my platoon went down.
This is when I had an armored cab platoon.
And we went down there, and we were riding around, just going up and down the streets real slow, waving to the kids, throwing them candy.
You know, it was like a big parade.
And this jeep with this American advisor comes tearing up to the front of the column and stops my platoon leader.
His name was Lieutenant Ole.
I think he's a captain in the Indiana Highway Patrol now.
And they stopped our column there and the guy says, hey, would you guys like to get into a firefight?

Well, we'd been in country a month and a half and we fired at some snipers and, you know, we had a little H&I at night and we fired some artillery here and there just to see, you know, keep in practice because we were all recon and we like to keep up with those things.
So,
Lieutenant Owen said, why sure, we'd be glad to help you.
So we go over to the airport, and there's a railroad running right next to the airport, and there was a big dike there.
And we see all these South Vietnamese soldiers laying alongside this dike, and they're all pointing over towards the northeast, and there was a little village, and it was surrounded by sugar cane.
And we kept, we didn't hear any rounds going off, we didn't hear any firing or anything like this.
Well, what had happened is the South Vietnamese were on one side,
And there was a B.C.
heavy weapons company inside the village on the other side, and nobody had fired around yet.
So they come to get this armored camp platoon because we had .50 caliber machine guns.
We had a .50 caliber on each PC.
We had two M60 machine guns on each PC.
We didn't have any gun shields yet because those were new and we hadn't received them.
So all we had up there was the machine guns.
And then...
Of course, we didn't have the other two guys in the back for the machine guns because we had left them on the bridge.
So what we had in each PC was a driver, we had a vehicle commander on the .50 caliber, and we had one man in the back, which was on an M79, what we called a Blooper.
Shot a 40-millimeter shell.
And so that's all we had in these 10 tracks.
And we had our little cab tenants flying off the antennas and stuff, you know.
We were just real hot to try.
Never been shot at before.
Didn't really know what we were doing.
I'd been in the Army 10 years and had participated in a lot of live fire exercises, but this was going to be my first time.

So when we got over to the berm and they told us exactly where they were and then you hear this little L-19 circling around up there saying, I see them, I see them, they're in the village, you know, and they're just sitting there eating.
So we got...
We got online, and we went up over the berm, and we got into the sugar cane.
Well, we lost sight of each other.
We were real close when we first started out to maintain eye contact.
But after that, I got on the radio, and I said, look for the antennas, the little cap, and it's on the antennas to keep you online.
I said, we'll go up here about another 50 meters.
We'll take a hard left, and we'll come online into the village.
Well, we came online just to the edge of the village,
And we broke out a sugar cane field, and I saw this guy standing over next to the wall of this last building over there.
And he had his rifle in his arms, and he was standing there smoking a cigarette.
Well, to tell you the truth, I didn't know if he was a good guy or a bad guy.
But I shot him with my .50 caliber, picked him clean up off the ground, and held him up there for about 10 seconds.
And after that, I want you to know that just all hell broke loose.
I mean, it seemed like the whole village exploded.
fifties were going off, people were yelling on the radio, I'm hit, I'm hit, and we stayed in there for about 35 minutes.
Now, we were using armored piercing incendiary rounds in our .50 caliber machine guns.
We picked it up from the Navy.
And as those rounds would go through something, they'd catch it on fire.
So it took about 30 seconds there after everybody got off their first 50 rounds.
We had the whole village burning.

And we were receiving a lot of rounds back, a lot of automatic weapons, AKs, a couple of heavy machine guns, because they were tearing some holes in those PCs that were supposed to be armored vehicles.
Well, don't believe everything you hear, okay?
And it got pretty bad in there, and after a while, we started throwing grenades into the hedgerows and stuff, and then the firing just stopped.
So...
We got a hold of the guy in the L-19.
He says, yeah, they're going out the backside of the village, and they're running into the sugar cane, heading for a tree line, which was about 900 meters away.
But they had cover in the sugar cane fields all the way over there.
So we started, Lieutenant Ole started, you know, doing some artillery adjusting and was using the guy in the L-19 as a spotter, but we were using our guns
off the fire base that we came from, which was just north of there.
So this was actually the first day of Tet, but, you know, nobody had told us about Tet except it was going to be a ceasefire and nothing was going to happen.
And we couldn't figure out why the Arvin were still laying back there on the berm.
So we pulled back to the far side of the berm
and use the Arvin as security, and we checked our weapons and stuff again, and we're all laughing, and we got a couple guys medevaced.
One guy took a round right through the palm of his hand.
Another one had his ear shot off, and, you know, a couple things like that.
But it had, you know, now we're all excited, and it hadn't hit us on what, you know, you can get killed doing this, you know.
But, uh,
We said, okay, if they went out to the northeast side of the village, then we'll just run around there.
We'll go around the village and we'll hit them again.
Well, we went around there, and we couldn't find them.
So we've got our PCs parked about 25 meters apart.
I and a guy named B.J.
Babbage, which is another vehicle commander, we get down off our PCs and walk over to our platoon leader's track.
Now, we're out in an open field.
And we're standing there smoking a cigarette and jacking the jaw a little bit, talking about how crummy the VC are because they won't stand and fight and everything.
And some guy from the sugar cane field opens up on us with a machine gun.
Well, as I am hastily moving back to my vehicle, I lost my sunglasses.
And they were prescription sunglasses.
That's the basic thing that I remember about that day that I got upset because I lost my sunglasses.
So we started shooting up the sugarcane fields, burning it, and everything else.
And it was starting to get dark.
So we were going to have to move out and go back up north and secure our three bridges.
So we did that because we were just down there on loan to them.
Well, the next morning, they called us and said, Hey, we went in with the Arvin through the village and have determined that y'all killed 126 B.C.,
And we've got the weapons and the radios, and we've got a good body count.
And we said, well, that's just great.
But we can't give you guys credit for it because the Arvins were there, and we're trying to build up their morale and everything.
So we made it known that the Arvin wiped out a heavy weapons company of 126 men.
I said, well, ain't this something.
So we went back down there, and while we were,
Moving back down there, they had brought the whole cab troop.
Now we're talking about four platoons of ten vehicles each.
They had brought the whole cab troop up that night to help secure the western side of Quang Nam out by the airport.
And I'm glad they brought the whole cab troop up there and we went back and secured our bridges.
Because when we got back up there, there were PCs smoking all over the place.
They'd been blown up.
They had about 12 guys killed.
And that's when the gooks, the VC, came out with their RPG-7s and their B-40 rockets.
See, they thought they were just going to waltz into town because they knew that the Arbors didn't have any armored vehicles there in that town.
And they didn't know, I guess, their intelligence was poor, and they didn't know that an armored cab unit had pulled into that AO.
But there we were.
So the first time they got in a fight down there, they didn't have anything to take care of their own vehicles.
But let me tell you that the RPG-7 is 20 years ahead of its time.
That has got to be the best anti-tank vehicle.
It will knock out any known tank on the battlefield today, with the exception of now the General Abrams.
It won't knock out the M1 tank.
But it'll do a job on anything else it wants to do.
I get carried away, so you'll have to stop me when you want to.
After that, we figured out, hey, this is Ted.
We were hit every night on the bridges.
Got bad there for a while.
After the next three weeks, it got bad.
We got rough bus, which were regional forces to come in and take care of the bridge security.
We brought the families in with them so we could give them security during the night.
During the day with the armored vehicles, we could operate 10 or 15 clicks off the road and still get back in and secure the bridges and stuff at night.

Fire missions all the time, snipers all night long, snappers trying to infiltrate your wire and blow you the bridges to cut your supply line because we were, we straddled Highway 1, the whole 11th Infantry Brigade did, basically all the way down from the Bonson Plains
to about five flicks south of Chew Line was the 11th Infantry Brigade area of operations.
And every once in a while, we'd go down and eat chow with the 173rd, who was at LZ English, which they were in the box on planes.
Crazy outfit.
They used to throw hand grenades at each other in the chow line, just, you know, to scare people.
Did Arvin help you while you were taking that village, or did they just stay?
No, they stayed back there on the backside of the berm.
And I can understand that because they had M1 carbines and they had M1 rifles and hand grenades.
They were a typical infantry unit.
They didn't have any automatic weapons with them at the time.
About a week after that, that Auburn battalion got overrun by the 41st VC Regiment.
and was completely annihilated.
They lost all their weapons, all their uniforms and everything.
So for the next four or five weeks in our area of operation, you didn't know who was shooting at you.
You know, it could have been the same bunch wearing GI clothes that they got off this Arvin battalion, and they were using American weapons.
So it got hard to tell who was who there for a while until you got it all sorted out.
But during Tet, you didn't have to call anybody and say, hey, we're being shot at.
We need to return fire or anything like that.
You know, you knew you were in a combat zone, and you just reacted.
What do you think of the Arvin and Greenwood?
I was afraid he was going to ask me that question.
I think the Arvins, because of the fact that they've been fighting for over 100 years,
And they had played games with the French and the Chinese and the Japanese, but they were just flat tired.
And they had seen so much suffering that, you know, if you killed one of their family members, they'd cry for a few minutes, and after that they just got up and went home.
There were some good Arvin units.
I worked with an Arvin unit, which was the 14th Arvin Cav Squadron,
It was a regiment that was, this was the second time I was in Vietnam.
And they operated out of Pleiku.
And they had a little colonel that just thought that the best VC was a dead VC.
And he didn't believe in the Chew Hoi program.
And he certainly didn't believe in taking prisoners.
And he had M76s, which was a real fast little tank.
that we had given him.
And he just went all over the Pleiku area and up and down the Cambodian border killing as many people as he could.
And it was a good unit.
They would stand and fight.
They had a special scarf that they wore.
And you just didn't fool around with those Colonel's units.
There were good American units and there were good Arvin units and there were bad American units and there were bad Arvin units.
I think towards the end of the war, I was there again in 1771.
I think at first in 67 and 68, the Army was sort of like we were.
I think they really had a grip on it and were starting to be trained good.
They were getting equipment from us.
They were starting to establish a spirit of corps and morale, and that they really thought they could do something.
Some of their range units were just outstanding.
I think in 70 and 71, when I was back over there again, they saw the Americans pulling out and cutting down the size of the forces that we had over there.
And I think their morale and their spirit of war started going.
They were slipping.
And instead of fighting, they'd move out.
During Tet, which was supposed to be their holiday, same as the PC's,
I believe they were basically all on holiday.
And it took them a while to get their units back together and to get organized and to realize that, hey, here's a major thrust towards the South Vietnamese country.
And everybody's got to fight.
And I just think that they were tired.
They had already had brothers and sisters and parents killed.
Some of them had already been wounded two or three times, and they just never saw an end to it.
And we can go over there, and if we were lucky, we spent 12 months there.
We'd get a million dollar wound, or we'd come home.
There's a big difference in fighting in somebody else's country than fighting on your own.
I'd hate to see a war break out along the Mexican border or in Texas, and us have to fight and defend the United States and have the fighting actually take place in our own country.
Because then you've got to worry about your loved ones,
You've got to worry about all those kind of things, you know, about your wife and your kids.

And when you're in another country doing all this fighting, you know they're back home going to school, eating three meals a day, the electricity's still on, the water's still running, they got indoor plumbing.
It's a big difference.
I like the South End.
These people, on the whole, are a beautiful group of people.
I felt sorry for them.
And unlike a lot of other GIs that were in South Vietnam, I'm glad it was there instead of here.
And I'm glad it was them instead of me.
Did you try to work, or did y'all work in any pacification programs?
Pacification programs.
We moved what we knew to be hardcore VC strongholds
We'd go in and we'd burn the hootches down, confiscate all the rice, shoot the livestock, and we'd herd up all the people and we'd take them out and we moved them into a big village.
Now you got these villages out in the mountains where the water runs pure,
They've been farming the same land for 50 or 60 years.
And they've lived and born and died several generations in the same mud hut, you know.
And then all of a sudden here these foreigners come in and destroy everything that their generations have lived and built.
And they move them into a village where there's 50,000 people in a city.
Now we're talking about rural country people.
And you move them into a city where there's bars and bright neon lights and easy money and a black market and say, now this is where you have to live and work and join the Arvin army.

And you're talking to people that fought at Thin Ben Pew and thrown the French out, and now they've gone back to farming, they're relaxed, they don't want nothing to do with the Arvids, they don't want nothing to do with the NVA, and they certainly didn't want anything to do with the ugly Americans.
So I think the pacification program, I better not say that on tape, I think it was a mistake.
I think the idea that some of the Marine Corps units had
is instead of moving people out of their villages, they'd move in five-man teams and help secure that village so they could harvest their rice and live a peaceful coexistence.
And the five-man Marine Corps teams kept the VC out of the villages, you know, and protected.
Now, you lost a lot of Marines sometimes because there was good political value for the VC to get into that kind of village.
you know, and get to the village chief and stuff like that.
But to me, that kind of program would have done more for us than anything else.
I think there was a lot of money wasted and lost for 10 roads and pacification programs that never got to the villager.
It stopped off someplace on the way down.
And all the stuff that was meant for that villager never got to it.
Black Market...
corrupt South Vietnamese officials, corrupt American officials.
One of the biggest trucking companies in South Vietnam was a share owner that was Lady Bird Johnson.
Not once did they ever get ambushed or hit because they were paying their taxes to the D.C. that the American soldiers were fighting.
If you put an American truck out there and paint that sucker OD and let it go down the road by itself, it'll never get to where it's going.
But them 18-wheelers, they'd get on the highway and no trouble.
Go straight into wherever they wanted to go.
Makes you think, doesn't it?
First time I went to South Vietnam, I was doing it for God and country and Mom's apple pie.
I'd been a soldier all my life, had been brought up in it, believed in my country, believed in my leaders and everything.
If you would have cut me, I would have bled O.D.,
That's how hardcore I was about the military.
About halfway through my tour, I changed all that.
And after that, it just became survival.
I got out of the armored cab unit.
I went into long-range recon.
I didn't like working with American units.
I'd take five men and go out and stay four days and come back in three and go out four days and come back in three.
And that's how I did the rest of my tour.
I did a lot of work with Charlotte Company, 75th Ranger Battalion, and Major Hudson was probably one of the finest officers that I've ever met.
And that's the way he fought his war, and I liked it that way.
It was things that I'd been trained for all my life, was counterinsurgency and ambushes, and I liked it.
And I did a good job at it.
I'm here.
Was there any one event or was it a community event that made you change your way of thinking?

It was seeing a number of things, the pacification program, it was seeing armed soldiers and young men of military age riding around on motorcycles, pimping for girls, and it was seeing 18 and 19-year-old kids getting killed when they were American kids.
Stop.
Take a break.
Where did you go to do your long range cruise?
Well, I'd already done most of it.
I did it in Europe.
I did it at Fort Hood.
I guess I got started at Fort Hood.
They had an H-13 there and I couldn't find anybody dumb enough to fly around with a pilot because it was a helicopter
It was getting to be new, and they were using it for artillery fire, but now they were going to use it for recon.
So I got started there, and we'd fly real low and slow, and I'd call back coordinates and stuff on where I saw the enemy and everything, and I'd just artillery fire for it.
This is when I was a buck sergeant.
And when I got to Fort Bliss, I made staff sergeant.
So when I was in Vietnam the first time, I was Staff Sergeant E6.
I was supposed to be a squad leader, but my platoon sergeant, as soon as we got to Vietnam, went up to Brigade Headquarters as an operational sergeant.
Instead of bringing in an E7, a new guy that didn't know all the guys in the platoon, they just sort of moved me over there.
and let me as a staff sergeant E6 and I took one of the buck sergeants that I knew that did real good and put him in as a squad leader.
And that's how I got that.
But I started long range patrols in Germany.
Went through a mini ranger course for the 10th special forces of Bantos.
Took my can platoon down there really.

infusion program where you can take a platoon down there from different units in Europe and go through a dirty uh yeah it was dirty but it was a 30-day course on land navigation ambushes and recon patrols and things like that like the special forces did and that was a lot of fun and I just wanted to get away from I wanted to be in Vietnam and I wanted to I wanted to be a good soldier and I wanted to do the things that I was trained to do
I felt handicapped a lot of times.
Vietnam was a squad leader's war.
It was the buck sergeant's war and the staff sergeant's war.
And by the time you called people up to get permission to do this or move here or can we put fire on this area or something like that, hey, the gooks were already gone.
So you wasted a lot of time.
But when you were on long-range patrols, you were given specific missions.
and the majority of them was just recon, find large troop movements and stuff like that, and then call it back in, and then they'd bring out a large American force to make contact.
Sometimes we would maintain visual contact.
Sometimes they'd say, well, we don't have anybody that's free to operate at this time, so you need to interdict and either ambush if it's not too large, or
call in an air strike or an artillery fire.
You know, and do as much damage as you can and then get out of the area.
So those were the kind of things that I liked.
It was more of an individual thing.
Were you still around duck foe when you changed?
Yeah, we operated out of duck foe.
Most every battalion had a squad of guys that did their recon stuff for them.
The division had a alert platoon and they did long range patrol.
And then you had, each division had a company of rangers that they used.
And Charlie County 75th Rangers was the one that I remember best because of Major Hudson in 1771.
But it got you away from the regular fighting.
You didn't sit up in a foxhole all night worrying about the GI to your right and what he was going to do.
If you had the right guys in your team, you knew exactly what they were going to do.
The platoon that I took to Vietnam, I had 23 men wounded and I had three men killed out of 11 months and 16 days the first time I was in Vietnam.
And I trained every one of those guys.
The three guys that got killed, if you send a whole unit together into South Vietnam, then that means if you leave them all together, they all have to rotate at the same time.
So right after we got in country, we had to infuse
15% of the organization.
So that meant that we had to get rid of 15% of our people and send them to different units.
And my three guys ended up, they went down to the 11th Cav.
And that's where they got killed, with the 11th Cav.
They didn't get killed in the 11th Cav.
They had a lot of guys wounded, you know.
And that was all.
While you were there the first time, were there any problems with spraying and drugs or alcohol?
Were there any about short time or anything like that?
No, everybody had a short time on their calendar.
That was just something that the first couple of weeks you really didn't pay any attention to something like that because, you know, you were doing a tour of duty.
It was just like 13 months in going to Korea or a two-year tour of duty in Germany because we hadn't done any fighting yet.
But once the fighting started, everybody started as short-timers, countenance.
I don't remember any fracking in the 11th and 15th Brigades, not the time that I was with them, 67 or 68.
These are the same officers and men that had trained together in Hawaii on a whole.
So there was a lot of respect and admiration for each other.
When we were back at the fire base,
We didn't get much beer.
Certainly wasn't any hard liquor.
We had an opportunity to drink two or three beers.
I think we were supposed to be issuing two beers per man per day.
You didn't see that out in the bush.
So when you got back to the fire base, there would be a connex container full of about 40 cases of beer.
So in three days, you could drink about 40 cases of beer.
But in those three days, you're supposed to get issued new fatigues, clean your weapons, check them out, drill them again, draw new equipment and supplies.
You know, just sort of stand down and rest when you're getting ready to go back out again.
You can smell pot a mile away.
And I can walk into a barracks and...
It can have four floors to it and I can tell you almost what room it is on the fourth floor of the smoking pot.
Just with my nose.
So, if I can smell it, the VC can smell it.
We didn't use cologne and we didn't use a lot of other things.
Now, we smoked cigarettes and some of us chewed tobacco.
I know that's a bad habit, but that's better than lighting up a cigarette at night.
I don't do it anymore, but I did then.
I didn't see much pot smoking.
Really didn't know at the time what it was.
I do know that if you wanted to stay up for three days in a row, that you could get a big old red pill from the medic.
And it turned out later that I found out it was speed.
I guess I was pretty naive when it came to drugs and things like that.
Because in my military service, we just never had that.
Turned out that the first driver for my PC that I had while I was still with the 11th Infantry Brigade was from Haight-Ashbury.

So he knew all about those drugs, and he educated me in what this is and what was that, and didn't do it in my presence, because he knew that I was one of the guys that believed that you had to be 100% all the time, or you wasn't going to come out of it.
So I guess it was there.
I didn't see any pothead
bunkers like they had in that movie Catoon.
And I didn't see a lot of guys drunk.
It was just something you didn't do because you never knew when you were going to get hit.
You could drink a couple of beers and not get drunk.
Still enjoy the beers in the cool of the evening and smoke your cigarette before the sun went down.
Now in 1771,

You know, you have to set that whole thing up because there was GIs that went to Vietnam that were geared to fight, and all of a sudden, in 1771, the war's standing down as far as the American GI is concerned, so they don't really let him get out there in the bush anymore.
I went to the 4th Entry Division, which I considered a national guard outfit, and for a regular Army sergeant to say something like that, that's terrible.
But I thought the 4th Entry Division was the rear end of the Army,
I was lucky enough, I went to the first of the 14th Cav, which was the Cav Squadron that they had.
And so that got me a little bit closer back to the people that I knew.
But while I was in Repo Depot, there was a sergeant there that had just come out.
He was coming back home to retire with 20 years of service.
He was the first sergeant, and he was walking down the street,
just about dark.
This was right outside the Red Bull Depot because when you come in, you go out at the same place.
And this was then on K. I put just north of what they call the golf course area where they used to have all their helicopters sitting there for the first air camp.
They left and we went in, the 4th Infantry Division went in there and took over their AO.
There's a big mountain right there on the edge of it.
Anyway, this first sergeant was walking down the street, and some black guy stepped out high on dope and put 20 rounds in him.
Killed him right there in the middle of the street.
Well, they walked over, and the MPs come, and they handcuffed the black guy.
And they took him to Bung Town.
And you know the guy got 10 to 15 years in labor.
He wasn't responsible for his actions because he was high on dope.
They should have shot the son of a bitch right there and saved everybody some money
I saw a 23-year-old captain, a company commander, stepped out of his orderly room one morning and was cutting half a machine gun, okay, by a black soldier that was on dope.
And what had happened is they had a hooch that this young West Point captain was going to break up.
And they had got word about it the night before, so the next morning,
When he stepped out of his armory room, they killed him.
We took a M48A1 tank down there and stuck the gun to through the door of the hooch and told those, I think there was anywhere from 10 to 15 guys in there, and they were all laughing and joking.
You know, did you see him fall?
Did you see him jerk around?
That kind of thing.
And we said, there's a 90-millimeter HE round in this gun to.
And you people have about five seconds to come out of there
And they came out with their hands over their heads.
They took them all to Bunktown.
